importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the current state of food supply challenges in Gaza, highlighting the urgency of humanitarian intervention following the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame covers the period since the US-brokered ceasefire began, during which food supplies have been gradually increasing but remain critically insufficient.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, currently at around 750 tonnes per day.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are operational, severely limiting the flow of humanitarian aid.
The WFP operates 26 food distribution points in Gaza, up from five, but still far short of the 145 planned for full coverage.
The US-brokered ceasefire under Donald Trump's 20-point plan is seen as vital for sustaining humanitarian access and preventing famine in northern Gaza.
Hamas has pledged to hand over 28 captives' bodies, having delivered 13 so far; the Rafah crossing remains closed until further notice, restricting access to southern Gaza.
Nutrition supplies for children and pregnant women have reached northern Gaza via southern routes, but not at sufficient scale.
Many Gazans are storing food due to uncertainty about the ceasefire’s longevity and potential resumption of hostilities.
Food delivered so far is sufficient for half a million people for only two weeks.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating international food aid and emergency food distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article as it reports on the current state of food delivery to Gaza, highlighting shortfalls and calling for more crossings to be opened.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, located in the south of the territory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two operational crossings currently allowing food supplies into Gaza, limiting access to humanitarian aid.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, located in the center of the territory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second operational crossing into Gaza, allowing limited food distribution through central areas of the Strip.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure of Rafah prevents additional humanitarian access, especially to northern Gaza, and is dependent on Hamas releasing captives' remains.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza, currently blocked to WFP access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been permitted to use this route for food distribution, limiting access to northern Gaza and exacerbating food insecurity.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President, who brokered the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s 20-point plan for ending the war includes commitments to full humanitarian aid, making him a key figure in the current ceasefire and aid access discussions.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister, who has stated that the Rafah crossing will remain closed until Hamas returns captives’ bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu’s position directly impacts access to humanitarian supplies via Rafah, reinforcing the political constraints on aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and military group that controls parts of Gaza and has pledged to return the remains of captured Israeli soldiers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas’s conditional agreement to hand over captives' bodies is tied to the reopening of key crossings, influencing the flow of humanitarian aid.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas responsible for delivering captives’ remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades confirmed the delivery of two more captives’ bodies, showing ongoing compliance with the ceasefire conditions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that daily food deliveries to Gaza have increased following a US-brokered ceasefire but remain critically low at about 750 metric tonnes per day—far below the target of 2,000 tonnes. Only two border crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently operational, severely restricting access to aid. The WFP operates 26 distribution points, still far below its goal of 145. Humanitarian access is dependent on political agreements, including Hamas’s pledge to return captives’ bodies, which has been partially fulfilled. The Rafah crossing remains closed, and the WFP has no access to the main Salah al-Din Street in northern Gaza. As a result, many Palestinians are storing food due to fears of future supply disruptions, and current supplies are only sufficient for half a million people for two weeks.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
